Award.AwardTitle: Developmental Buffering in a Gene Regulatory Network
Award.AbstractNarration: In living systems, noise in gene expression can lead to differences in phenotype, even among genetically identical cells. This project will study the basis for different phenotypes occurring in animals carrying the same genotype, using the development of the gut in the nematode C. elegans as a model. The genetic pathway controlling specification of the gut involves transient activation of the genes end-1 and end-3. Mutated versions of these genes have been introduced into C. elegans animals that lack the normal copies. Preliminary results show that only some embryos make gut, and that surviving adults have abnormal guts. This project will study the basis for these effects. First, the development of the gut in end mutant embryos will be examined at high resolution. Second, global gene expression in adult guts will be compared with normal animals, and possible defects in function of genes in the gut specification pathway will be tested. Third, sources of noise in the upstream-most components of gut specification will be measured, and genes whose products influence the stochastic specification of gut will be identified. Reverse genetics (using RNA interference), time lapse microscopy, and high-throughput sequencing of expressed genes (RNA-Seq) will be used. The experiments will describe gut development at high resolution in a new set of mutants, characterize defects in adult intestines derived from the mutant strains, and identify possible sources of gene expression noise in organ specification. The work has the potential to define new paradigms for how living systems manage inherent differences in gene expression during development. In the course of performing this work, the PI, himself of Hispanic descent, will train undergraduates from the diverse UC Riverside campus, and a graduate student. A laboratory course for first-year Biology undergraduates will train students in research and allow them to carry out original research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The development of the gut (intestine) of the nematode C. elegans was investigated. This small animal is a model organism in which many questions can be asked about how different tissues develop from smaller numbers of earlier cells in the embryo.

In C. elegans the gut descends from a single cell called E, which divides several times to produce a 20-cell intestine. Prior work has identified how specific proteins cause this cell to make gut. The Maduro lab showed that a partial loss of function of the principal regulators, END-1 and END-3, altered the pattern of cell divisions in the E descendants. In those animals producing a functional gut, adults display a slowing of metabolism in favor of fat storage. This grant aimed to determine how the developing gut lineage responds to partial compromise of END-1/3, to determine why adult survivors have metabolic defects, and identify mechanisms that assure robust gut development.

The principal findings of this work were as follows:

1. The endoderm lineage is more plastic than an 'all-or-none' model of gut specification would predict. Evidence was found that parts of the gut lineage could adopt a gut fate while other parts did not. Most embryos that have compromised END-1/3 activity make more than 20 descendants from the E precursor. Despite this, the developing intestine shows a surprising ability to accommodate the extra cells into the gut.

2. The primary source of the embryonic and adult defects appears to be the timing of onset of the differentiation factor ELT-2. There appears to be a critical window of time in the early embryo in which appropriate cell cycle control and metabolic control must be established. In embryos where this does not occur, these become abnormal in a stochastic (random) way.

3. Surviving adults demonstrate metabolic changes that are consistent with an increase in storage of lipids. This increase in lipid storage is partially dependent on the conserved regulator FOXO/DAF-16.

4. Only a small percentage of genes in the differentiated intestine of specification-compromised adults is expressed differently. Most of these are related to metabolism, and one of them, a Nuclear Hormone Receptor gene, may be responsible for most of the lipid storage defects. When this gene is mutated in wild-type animals, they become highly compromised in their metabolism in favor of fat storage.

5. Dozens of genes were identified that influence gut specification. When the expression of these genes is reduced in mothers that are partially compromised for gut specification, their progeny embryos experience an increase or decrease in the ability to make gut. Some of these genes affect global gene expression, while others are genes for which no function is currently known.

6. Expression variation for the gut specification genes was measured quantitatively in collaboration with the Rifkin laboratory at UC San Diego. A model is being generated that can predict the responses of the gene network to perturbations.

Overall, the results allow us to conclude that (1) Robust and timely specification of gut is required for proper metabolism; (2) Descendants of the gut precursor E in C. elegans can acquire fates that are different from each other; (3) The C. elegans gut is remarkably plastic in its ability to accommodate extra gut cells, producing a functional intestine.

These findings can be extended to other animals, including humans. Most important is the demonstration that 'partial' specification can lead to an apparent normal development of descendant cells but still have defects in function. This means that for the programming of stem cells, it is important to activate early specification factors 'robustly' because at least some cell types may not fully compensate for weak activation. It is also possible that some human genetic diseases that are detected in adults are the result of minor abnormalities in gene expression in embryos.

Broader Impacts

The work performed has appeared in two published papers, with four more papers in preparation and an additional two papers published during the funding period. Aspects of the work have been reported at several meetings, including the Society for Developmental Biology meeting (2014) and International C. elegans Meetings (2013, 2015).

One PhD student and five undergraduates performed work on the project; two of the undergraduates (both minority students) are now in graduate programs at other institutions. Several useful strains were generated for use by the general scientific community.

Two offerings of an undergraduate laboratory course, Biology 20, were taught by the Principal Investigator, to a total of 36 students. These students learned molecular biology, genetics and RNA interference, and obtained practical lab experience on the use of model organisms for biological research.
